articles.headline: ‘Google Is a Monopolist,’ Judge Rules in Landmark Antitrust Case
articles.snippet: The ruling on Google’s search dominance was the first antitrust decision of the modern internet era in a case against a technology giant.
articles.abstract: The ruling on Google’s search dominance was the first antitrust decision of the modern internet era in a case against a technology giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google acted illegally to maintain a monopoly in online search, a federal judge ruled on Monday, a landmark decision that strikes at the power of tech giants in the modern internet era and that may fundamentally alter the way they do business.

articles.headline: Facing Mass Protests, Bangladesh Leader Quits, Setting Up Power Struggle
articles.snippet: Demonstrators defied a curfew, expecting another in a series of bloody crackdowns, but instead Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina fled.
articles.abstract: Demonstrators defied a curfew, expecting another in a series of bloody crackdowns, but instead Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina fled.
articles.lead_paragraph: They came prepared for violence. A day after about 100 people were killed in antigovernment protests, hundreds of thousands took to the streets of Dhaka, Bangladesh’s capital, defying a curfew imposed by the government and demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina.
articles.byline: By Saif Hasnat, Shayeza Walid and Anupreeta Das

articles.headline: Stocks Steady After Day of Wild Selling
articles.snippet: Wall Street rebounded on Tuesday, retracing some of the losses in the previous day’s rout. Stocks in Japan, the hardest hit by recent selling, jumped 10 percent.
articles.abstract: Wall Street rebounded on Tuesday, retracing some of the losses in the previous day’s rout. Stocks in Japan, the hardest hit by recent selling, jumped 10 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: A measure of calm returned to global markets on Tuesday, as stocks staged a modest recovery from the panic that had overtaken investors to start the week.
articles.byline: By River Akira Davis and Danielle Kaye

articles.headline: Waiting for a Wider War, Lebanese Civilians Feel Helpless
articles.snippet: Hezbollah’s conflict with Israel has already damaged south Lebanon. Now it could escalate, regardless of what anyone else in Lebanon thinks.
articles.abstract: Hezbollah’s conflict with Israel has already damaged south Lebanon. Now it could escalate, regardless of what anyone else in Lebanon thinks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The town in south Lebanon appeared deserted, its roads empty and its market shuttered, after months of fighting between Hezbollah and Israel across the nearby border made many residents flee.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Hwaida Saad and Diego Ibarra Sanchez

articles.headline: How the Google Antitrust Ruling May Influence Tech Competition
articles.snippet: Nearly a quarter-century after Microsoft lost a similar case, a judge’s decision that Google abused a monopoly in internet search is likely to have major ripple effects.
articles.abstract: Nearly a quarter-century after Microsoft lost a similar case, a judge’s decision that Google abused a monopoly in internet search is likely to have major ripple effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2000, a ruling in a U.S. antitrust case against Microsoft helped set the rules of competition for the digital giant of its day.

articles.headline: As Regulators Close In, Nvidia Scrambles for a Response
articles.snippet: With a 90 percent share of the A.I. chip market, the company is facing antitrust investigations into the possibility that it could lock in customers or hurt competitors.
articles.abstract: With a 90 percent share of the A.I. chip market, the company is facing antitrust investigations into the possibility that it could lock in customers or hurt competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nvidia rocketed to the top of the tech industry by providing the computer chips essential to building artificial intelligence. By the end of last year, it had more than a 90 percent share of those chips sold around the world.
articles.byline: By Tripp Mickle and David McCabe

articles.headline: Recession Fears May Be Overstated, but Not Unfounded
articles.snippet: The economy has repeatedly defied predictions of a downturn since the pandemic recovery began. Now signs of strength contend with shakier readings.
articles.abstract: The economy has repeatedly defied predictions of a downturn since the pandemic recovery began. Now signs of strength contend with shakier readings.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy has spent three years defying expectations. It emerged from the pandemic shock more quickly and more powerfully than many experts envisioned. It proved resilient in the face of both inflation and the higher interest rates the Federal Reserve used to combat it. The prospect many forecasters once considered imminent — a recession — looked increasingly like a false alarm.

articles.headline: The Tiny Chinese Restaurant That Became an Olympic Hot Spot
articles.snippet: A few blocks from the table tennis venue, a restaurant has become an unofficial (and unlikely) clubhouse for fans, team officials and athletes.
articles.abstract: A few blocks from the table tennis venue, a restaurant has become an unofficial (and unlikely) clubhouse for fans, team officials and athletes.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Tang Zhongqiu knows, there often comes a time in an Asian person’s trip to France when one grows weary of the endless parade of bread and seeks respite in a simple bowl of rice.
articles.byline: By Andrew Keh and Weiyi Cai

articles.headline: Tim Walz Is Kamala Harris’s Choice for Vice President
articles.snippet: The Minnesota governor, a former high school teacher and National Guard member, brings to the ticket Midwestern appeal and a plain-spoken way of taking on Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: The Minnesota governor, a former high school teacher and National Guard member, brings to the ticket Midwestern appeal and a plain-spoken way of taking on Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris, the Democratic nominee for president, has chosen Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate, elevating a former football coach whose rural roots, liberal policies and buzzy takedowns of former President Donald J. Trump have recently put him on the map.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein, Katie Rogers, Erica L. Green and Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: X, Owned by Elon Musk, Brings Antitrust Suit Accusing Advertisers of a Boycott
articles.snippet: The company claimed that members of the Global Alliance for Responsible Media coordinated to dissuade brands from advertising on X.
articles.abstract: The company claimed that members of the Global Alliance for Responsible Media coordinated to dissuade brands from advertising on X.
articles.lead_paragraph: X filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against the Global Alliance for Responsible Media, a coalition of major advertisers, claiming that it had violated antitrust laws by coordinating with brands to dissuade them from spending money on the social media platform.
